questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Secondary glaucoma

 

Explanation:

  • Secondary glaucoma is not an indication of PK but rather an early complication of the procedure.
  • It is a condition where increased intraocular pressure results from another underlying issue, and it typically requires treatment that addresses the underlying cause of the increased pressure, not corneal replacement.
  • PK addresses corneal diseases and issues directly, not intraocular pressure problems or secondary glaucoma.

Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK):

  • It is a type of Allografting (Allo-Keratoplasty) which is the replacement of a patient’s diseased cornea with a healthy donor cornea.
  • Full-thickness grafting.

Indications for Penetrating Keratoplasty:

 

Optical
  • Corneal opacity (Option A ruled out)
  • Bullous keratopathy
  • Corneal dystrophies
  • Advanced keratoconus (Option C ruled out)
 

Therapeutic

To replace an inflamed cornea that does not respond to conventional therapy

Tectonic Graft

To restore the integrity of the eyeball, e.g., after corneal perforation or in cases of significant corneal thinning.

Cosmetic

To improve the appearance of the eye (Option B ruled out)

Complications: (ak142)

  • Early Complications:
    • Flat anterior chamber
    • Iris prolapse
    • Infection
    • Secondary glaucoma (Option D)
    • Epithelial defects
    • Primary graft failure
  • Late Complications:
    • Graft rejection
    • Recurrence of disease
    • Astigmatism

questions.text: A 30 y/o contact lens wearer presents with very severe eye pain, blurred vision, and discomfort in his right eye. O/E, the following corneal finding is noted. Based on the image and the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acanthamoeba Keratitis

 

Explanations:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that is often out of proportion to the clinical findings, along with features such as perineural infiltrates and, in advanced cases, ring-shaped abscesses.
  • The image provided shows these hallmark signs.

 

Examination Findings in Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

Symptoms:

  • Blurred Vision: Common in corneal conditions due to the disruption of the cornea's transparent surface.
  • Discomfort: Significant discomfort in the affected eye.
  • Severe Pain: Pain is often out of proportion to clinical signs, a key clinical clue.

Signs:

Early Disease:

  • Irregular and Greyish Epithelium: Early sign indicating amoebic invasion.
  • Pseudodendrites: Lesions resembling herpetic keratitis
  • Limbitis and Stromal Infiltrates: Inflammation at the corneal-scleral junction with diffuse or focal infiltrates in the anterior stroma.
  • Perineural Infiltrates (Radial Keratoneuritis): Hallmark sign, radial streaks extending towards the cornea's centre, pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Advanced Disease:

  • Ring Abscess: Characteristic of advanced infection, where infiltrates form a ring-shaped abscess.
  • Stromal Opacification and Vascularisation: Corneal opacity and new blood vessel growth, leading to significant vision impairment.
  • Corneal Melting: Serious complication where corneal tissue breaks down, often at the infiltrate edges.
  • Scleritis: Reactive inflammation of the sclera, not a direct infection extension.

Herpes Simplex Keratitis (Option A) typically presents with dendritic ulcers and less severe pain relative to Acanthamoeba keratitis.

  • The image and symptoms described, especially the severe pain out of proportion to clinical signs, are more indicative of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis (Option B) usually presents with feathery-edged infiltrates and satellite lesions.

  • While it can cause significant discomfort, the pain level and clinical features (e.g., perineural infiltrates) seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis are distinctive.

Bacterial Keratitis (Option D) typically presents with a more prominent purulent discharge and a dense, localized infiltrate.

  • The disproportionate pain and the clinical signs in the image are more consistent with Acanthamoeba keratitis.

questions.text:
Match the Following:
 


	
		
			
			1) 
			
			
			a) Bacterial Keratitis
			
		
		
			
			2) 

			
			
			
			b) Superficial Punctate Keratitis
			
		
		
			
			3) 

			
			
			
			c) Pseudodendritis
			
		
		
			
			4) 

			
			
			
			d) Dendritic Ulcer
			
		
		
			
			5) 
			
			
			e) Nummular Keratitis
			
		
		
			
			6) 

			
			
			
			f) Fungal Keratitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-c; 2-e; 3-b; 4-f; 5-d; 6-a.

 

Explanation:

Image

Description

Bacterial Keratitis:


 

A corneal epithelial defect with an infiltrate (a larger area of corneal involvement) and significant circumcorneal injection, often with a hypopyon.

Fungal Keratitis:



 

Grey or yellow-white stromal infiltrate with indistinct fluffy margins, often with satellite lesions, or a yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate in Candida keratitis.

Superficial Punctate Keratitis:


 

This term describes any corneal epithelial disturbance with a dot-like morphology, including conditions like Thygeson superficial punctate keratitis.

Nummular Keratitis:

Characterized by fine granular subepithelial deposits surrounded by a halo of stromal haze.

Dendritic Ulcer:

Linear branching ulcer with terminal bulbs, the base of which stains well with fluorescein, and where the virus-laden cells at the margin of the ulcer stain with rose Bengal.

Pseudodendritis:

Corneal epithelial lesions that are smaller and finer than herpes simplex dendrites, have tapered ends without terminal bulbs, and stain better with rose Bengal than with fluorescein.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female contact lens wearer with severe eye pain and blurred vision shows a ring-shaped corneal infiltrate, and radial keratoneuritis on examination. Corneal scraping showed the presence of cysts. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Topical polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB)

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and findings point to Acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • PHMB is an amoebicidal agent effective against both the trophozoites and cysts of Acanthamoeba.
  • It is the treatment of choice for Acanthamoeba keratitis, especially when cysts are identified.

 

Investigations and Treatment of Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

 

Investigations:

  • Corneal Scraping:
    • The primary method for obtaining tissue for examination.
    • Scrape the margins and base of the lesion after applying a non-preserved topical anaesthetic.
  • Staining:
    • PAS (Periodic acid–Schiff) and Calcofluor white: Highly effective for visualizing Acanthamoeba cysts.
    • Gram and Giemsa stains: Less sensitive but can also demonstrate cysts.
  • Culture: Definitive diagnosis by culturing on non-nutrient agar with dead E. coli.
  • Additional Investigations:
    • Immunohistochemistry: Uses antibodies to detect specific Acanthamoeba antigens.
    • PCR: Useful for detecting Acanthamoeba DNA.
    • In Vivo Confocal Microscopy: Provides detailed images of Acanthamoeba cysts within the cornea.
  • Corneal Biopsy:
    • Considered if other diagnostic methods are inconclusive.

Treatment Modalities:

  • Debridement: Removal of infected epithelium to enhance topical medication penetration.
  • Topical Amoebicides:
    • PHMB (polyhexamethylene biguanide) 0.02% and Chlorhexidine 0.02%: Effective against both trophozoites and cysts.
    • Hexamidine: More effective than Propamidine (Brolene).
  • Topical Steroids:
    • Considered for persistent inflammation after two weeks of anti-amoebic treatment.
    • Caution against use if corneal thinning is present.
  • Pain Management: Oral NSAIDs are recommended for pain relief.
  • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Required for cases resistant to medical therapy or when corneal perforation occurs.

Topical moxifloxacin (Option A):

  • Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial keratitis.
  • It is not effective against Acanthamoeba, which is the suspected pathogen in this case based on clinical findings and the presence of cysts.

Oral acyclovir (Option B):

  • Acyclovir is an antiviral agent used primarily for herpes simplex keratitis.
  • It is ineffective against Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Topical corticosteroids (Option D):

  • While corticosteroids may be used cautiously for persistent inflammation after initiating anti-amoebic treatment, they are not first-line therapy and should be avoided initially due to the risk of worsening the infection if used prematurely.

questions.text: A 23 y/o male presents with B/L eye redness, pain, and severe blurring of vision. He has a history of congenital syphilis. O/E, there is a characteristic pinkish-red discolouration of the cornea with deep stromal vascularization. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this patient's condition during the healing stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ghost vessels

 

Explanations:

  • The given features describe Syphilitic Interstitial Keratitis.
  • Ghost vessels are remnants of previously filled blood vessels that become empty after the active inflammation of syphilitic interstitial keratitis resolves.
  • They are a characteristic finding during the healing stage of the condition.

 

Interstitial Keratitis (IK): Inflammation of the corneal stroma. Typically does not affect the corneal epithelium or endothelium initially.

 

Causes of IK:

  • Syphilis
  • Other infectious causes include tuberculosis, Lyme disease, parasitic infections (common in endemic areas)
  • Inflammatory/systemic disorders: Sarcoidosis, Cogan syndrome, HSV, VZV

Clinical Presentation of Syphilitic Interstitial Keratitis:


 

Aspect

Details

Symptoms

Acute anterior uveitis: Pain, redness, photophobia, blurred vision.

Severe blurring of vision during the active phase.

Clinical Signs: Active Stage
  • Salmon Patch Appearance: Pinkish-red discoloration due to deep stromal vascularization and clouding.
  • Limbitis: Inflammation at the corneal-scleral junction.
  • Granulomatous Anterior Uveitis: Large inflammatory deposits (keratic precipitates) on the corneal endothelium.

Clinical Signs: Healing Stage
  • Ghost Vessels: Empty blood vessels leaving faint tracks.
  • Stromal Scarring: Feathery appearance from scarring.
  • Corneal Thinning: This may lead to irregular astigmatism and vision impairment.
  • Band Keratopathy: Calcium deposition as a late complication.

 

 

Pseudodendrites (Option A) are typically associated with herpetic keratitis, not with interstitial keratitis caused by syphilis.

Ring-shaped abscess (Option C): Ring-shaped abscesses are seen in advanced Acanthamoeba keratitis, not in syphilitic interstitial keratitis.

Radial keratoneuritis (Option D) is a hallmark feature of Acanthamoeba keratitis and is not seen in syphilitic interstitial keratitis.

questions.text:
A 19 y/o female presents with a history of progressive worsening of vision that is not fully corrected by glasses. After evaluation, she is diagnosed with keratoconus. Which of the following examination findings are seen in keratoconus?
 


	Munson's sign
	Scissor reflex
	Vogt striae
	Fleischer ring
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:
Keratoconus

  • Definition: Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.
  • Pathology: Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features

  • Symptoms:
    • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism, uncorrectable by glasses.
    • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, halos around lights.
    • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation.
    • Visual loss mainly from irregular astigmatism and myopia; secondary loss due to corneal scarring.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Thinning & Bulging: The Cornea thins near the centre and bulges forward, with the cone apex slightly below the corneal centre.
  • Specific Signs:
    • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
    • Placido Disc Irregularity: Circles appear irregular.
    • Slit-Lamp Examination:
      • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
      • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring: Brownish ring around the cone, possibly due to haemosiderin in the epithelium.
      • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
      • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, best seen with a slit lamp, disappearing with external pressure (vs Haab striae: They are curvilinear breaks in Descemet's membrane, resulting acutely from stretching of the cornea in primary congenital glaucoma).
    • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
    • Distant Direct Ophthalmoscopy: Annular dark shadow (oil droplet reflex) separating central and peripheral cornea. A ring of shadow concentric with the margin in the red reflex, resembling an oil droplet.
    • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular Astigmatism: Progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism in later stages, poorly corrected by glasses.
    • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down.
    • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
      • Corneal Topography: The most sensitive method for early detection (Forme Fruste Keratoconus) shows the shape of the corneal surface.

questions.text:
Question:
A 22 y/o male with a history of worsening vision despite wearing rigid gas-permeable lenses now complains of increased visual distortion. O/E, his corneal topography shows progressive ectasia, and he is advised to consider treatment options to halt disease progression. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate to stabilize the condition and improve contact lens tolerance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL)

 

Explanation:

  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) is the most appropriate treatment for stabilizing keratoconus progression and improving contact lens tolerance in this patient.
  • It works by strengthening the corneal stroma through the cross-linking of collagen fibres, which helps to halt the progression of ectasia, thereby preserving vision and enhancing the effectiveness of contact lenses.

Treatment of Keratoconus

  • Spectacle Correction:
    • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
    • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.
  • Contact Lenses:
    • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
    • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.
  • Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):
    • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
    • Involves riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
    • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.
  • Keratoplasty :
    • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
    • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
    • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.
  • Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :
    • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
    • Less effective in halting progression.

Spectacle correction (Option A):

  • Glasses are ineffective in stabilizing or treating corneal ectasia; they only correct refractive errors.

Intracorneal ring segments (INTACS) (Option B):

  • INTACS can improve vision by reshaping the cornea, but they do not stop disease progression.
  • They may be used in conjunction with CXL to achieve better outcomes.

Penetrating keratoplasty (Option D):

  • This is a full-thickness corneal transplant typically reserved for advanced cases where other treatments have failed.
  • It is not a first-line treatment for early or moderate ectasia.

questions.text: A 50 y/o patient presents for a corneal transplant evaluation. The patient has a history of systemic infections, including tuberculosis, and is seeking a corneal graft for a therapeutic indication. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for cornea donation in this patient?

choices.text: Death due to an unknown cause

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Death due to an unknown cause
 

Explanation:

  • Death due to an unknown cause: This is an absolute contraindication as it could signal serious undiagnosed conditions.

Keratoplasty

  • Definition: Surgical procedure where the patient's diseased cornea is replaced with a healthy clear cornea.

Types of Keratoplasty:

  • Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK): Full-thickness grafting.
  • Lamellar Keratoplasty (LK): Partial-thickness grafting.

Donor Tissue

  • Timing: Donor eye removal should be within 6 hours of death (up to 12 hours in cold climates).
  • Storage: Stored under sterile conditions.
  • Evaluation:
    • Biomicroscopic Examination: Assess the condition of corneal epithelium, stroma, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium. Grades: excellent to poor.
    • Specular Microscopy: Check endothelial cell count and morphology.
    • Microbial Evaluation: Culture from conjunctival swab.
    • Serological Screening: Test for HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and syphilis.

 

Contraindications for cornea donation

Absolute contraindications

Relative contraindications

1) Death due to an unknown cause

 

2) Systemic infections

  • HIV
  • Hepatitis
  • Congenital rubella
  • TB
  • Syphilis
 

3) CNS infection or diseases

  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Rabies
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
 

4) Most haematological malignancies

  • Leukaemia
  • Lymphoma
  • Myeloma and other myeloproliferative disorders and syndromes
  • Ocular inflammation (Option C ruled out)
  • Any congenital or acquired disorders of the Eye or previous ocular surgery (including corneal laser surgery) (Option B ruled out)
  • Retinoblastoma (Option D ruled out)
  • Malignant tumours or ocular metastases in the anterior segment of the eye.

questions.text: A donor cornea is harvested and needs to be preserved for a planned corneal transplant for 10 days. Which of the following storage methods is most appropriate for preserving the donor cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Optisol GS

 

Explanation:

  • Optisol GS is designed for intermediate-term storage, effective for up to 2 weeks, making it suitable for preserving the cornea for up to 10 days.

Storage of Cornea

 

Short-term Storage

(24 to 96 hours)

Intermediate-term Storage

(up to 2 weeks)

Long-term Preservation

(months to years):
  • Moist Chamber Method: Preserve the whole globe at 4°C in a refrigerator for up to 48 hours.
  • McCarey Kaufman (M-K) Medium:
  • Pink-colored medium containing TC-199, Dextran-40, HEPES buffer, and gentamicin.
  • Optisol GS:
  • Contains chondroitin sulfate, dextran, ascorbic acid, vitamin B12, ATP precursors, gentamicin, and streptomycin.
  • Other Media: Cornisol, Eusol, and Life-GE medium also available for up to 2 weeks.
  • Glycerine Preservation: Effective for 3-4 weeks.
  • Organ Culture Method: Preserves cornea at 30°C to 37°C for up to 35 days.
  • Cryopreservation: Preserves corneal button at -70°C for up to 1 year.

 

Moist Chamber Method (Option A): Suitable only for short-term storage up to 48 hours, so it is not appropriate for a 10-day storage period.

McCarey Kaufman (M-K) Medium (Option B): Effective for short-term storage up to 96 hours, which is insufficient for 10 days.

Cryopreservation (Option D): Although it preserves corneal tissue for up to 1 year, it is not typically used for the 10-day storage period due to its specific requirements and more complex handling.

questions.text: A 70 y/o woman presents with severe pain in her right eye and forehead, along with a rash that started 5 days ago. She was diagnosed with Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO). Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of her condition?

choices.text: Systemic steroids alone are sufficient to manage HZO
Antiviral therapy is started within 72 hours of rash onset.
Postherpetic neuralgia is less common in patients over 70 years of age.
Topical antiviral therapy is not recommended to manage eye involvement in HZO.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antiviral therapy is started within 72 hours of rash onset

 

Explanation:

  • Antiviral therapy is most effective when started within 72 hours of rash onset, its effectiveness diminishes significantly after this period.
  • However, treatment may still be considered beyond 72 hours, especially in severe cases, but the benefits are reduced.

 

Treatment of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO):

  • Goals: Reduce viral replication, manage inflammation, and alleviate symptoms.

1. Antiviral Therapy:

  • Early Intervention: Start within 72 hours of rash onset to reduce severity, duration, postherpetic neuralgia, and late ophthalmic complications.
  • Drugs of Choice:
    • Aciclovir: 800 mg five times daily for 7-10 days.
    • Valaciclovir: 1 g three times daily for 7-10 days.
    • Famciclovir: 500 mg three times daily for 7 days.

2. Systemic Steroids:

  • Usage: Often used for moderate to severe HZO, especially with neurological complications; always paired with antivirals.
  • Benefits: Reduces acute pain and expedites skin healing.
  • Drawbacks: No effect on postherpetic neuralgia; avoid immunodeficiency.

3. Topical Treatments:

  • Skin Lesions: Use drying agents, antiseptic solutions, and cold compresses.
  • Eye Involvement: Specific treatments depend on the chronic phase and manifestation.

4. Immunocompromised Patients:

  • Require specialized care.
  • Extended antiviral treatment and possibly intravenous administration.
  • Systemic steroids are generally not recommended.

Post-Herpetic Neuralgia:

  • Definition: Pain persisting over a month after rash healing.
  • Prevalence: Up to 75% in patients over 70. (Option C ruled out)
  • Treatment: Stepwise approach with analgesics, tricyclic antidepressants, anticonvulsants like gabapentin, and potentially opioids.

Systemic steroids alone are sufficient to manage HZO (Option A):

  • Systemic steroids should not be used as a monotherapy for HZO.
  • They must be combined with antiviral therapy to manage inflammation and pain effectively, as steroids alone do not reduce viral replication or prevent complications.

Topical antiviral therapy is not recommended to manage eye involvement in HZO (Option D):

  • Topical antiviral therapy in combination with systemic antiviral therapy is the standard of care for managing the viral infection.

questions.text:
A 45 y/o patient presents with worsening vision, mild pain, and redness 6 months after Penetrating Keratoplasty. Examination reveals the following. Which feature is most indicative of endothelial rejection?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Khodadoust Line

 

Explanation:

  • Khodadoust Line: This is a characteristic sign of endothelial rejection, marked by a demarcation line between healthy and damaged endothelium.
  • It is a key feature in diagnosing endothelial rejection.

 

 

CORNEAL GRAFT REJECTION

 

Incidence:

Less common than other organ transplants but can occur as early as 2 weeks and up to several years after keratoplasty.

 

Types of Rejection:

  • Epithelial Rejection
  • Stromal Rejection
  • Endothelial Rejection (most common and most likely to lead to graft failure)

Clinical Presentations of Corneal Graft Rejection:

  • Epithelial Rejection:Elevated epithelial rejection line staining with fluorescein.
    • Epithelial Rejection Line: Irregular elevated line in the epithelium. (Option D ruled out)
  • Subepithelial Infiltrates:
    • Known as Kayes dots. (Option B ruled out)
  • Stromal Rejection:
    • Sudden onset of full-thickness stromal haze in a previously clear graft.
    • Cellular Infiltration or Edema: In the stroma.
  • Endothelial Rejection:
    • Khodadoust Line: Demarcation line between healthy and damaged endothelium.
    • Diffuse Endothelial Rejection: Characterized by numerous keratic precipitates.
    • Endothelial Rejection Line: Linear deposition of white blood cells on the corneal endothelium.
  • Additional Signs:
    • Circumcorneal Congestion
    • Fresh Keratic Precipitates
    • Epithelial Edema
    • Increased Flare and Cells: In the anterior chamber. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following statements about lamellar keratoplasty are true except:

choices.text: It is indicated in pseudophakic bullous keratopathy
It has lower risk of graft rejection compared to Penetrating keratoplasty
Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) replaces 80-90% of the anterior stroma and is suitable when the endothelium is normal.
Descemet’s Stripping Automated Endothelial Keratoplasty (DSAEK) is performed when the endothelium is defective.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is indicated in pseudophakic bullous keratopathy

 

Explanation:

  • Keratoplasty: Commonly known as corneal transplantation, where a patient’s diseased cornea is replaced by healthy clear cornea.

 

Indications of Penetrating Keratoplasty:

  • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy
  • Corneal opacity
  • Corneal dystrophies
  • Advanced keratoconus
  • Marked corneal thinning

 

Indications of Endothelial Keratoplasty:

  • Fuchs endothelial dystrophy
  • Pseudophakic corneal edema
  • Posterior polymorphous dystrophy
  • Aphakic corneal edema
  • Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome
  • Failed corneal graft

 

KERATOPROSTHESIS

  • Keratoprosthesis is an artificial corneal device used for patients unsuitable for conventional keratoplasty.
  • Indications:
    • Bilateral blindness due to corneal diseases not amenable to keratoplasty
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
    • Chemical burns
  • Types of Keratoprosthesis:
    • Boston Keratoprosthesis (Boston K-Pro)
    • Alfa Cor Keratoprosthesis
    • Modified Osteo-Odonto-Keratoprosthesis (MOOKP)

questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			1) Arcus senilis
			
			
			a) 
			
		
		
			
			2) Band shaped Keratopatthy
			
			
			b) 

			
			
			{{caption_text}}
			
			
			
			 
		
		
			
			3) Vortex keratopathy
			
			
			c) 

			
			
		
		
			
			4) Salzmann nodular degeneration
			
			
			d) 

			
			
			{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

CORNEAL DEGENERATION

IMAGE

Arcus Senilis

 
  • Lipoid infiltration of the cornea. It is common in the elderly.
  • Begins as a crescentic grey or whitish arc around the corneal margins.
  • Extends to form a complete opaque ring around the cornea.
  • Thicker at the top and bottom; sharply defined on the peripheral side, fading towards the centre.
  • Typically no more than 1 mm wide.
  • Does not affect vision or corneal vitality.
  • Unrelated to secondary hypercholesterolemia.
  • Round opacity at a young age is called arcus juvenilis, caused by dyslipidemia.

Band Shaped Keratopathy

 
  • Common in chronic uveitis, aphakic eyes with prolonged silicone oil, and occasionally linked to hyperparathyroidism or vitamin D poisoning.
  • Characterized by a whitish band across the cornea with round ‘holes’ or cleaves.
  • Caused by hyaline infiltration and deposition of calcareous salts in the superficial stroma.
  • Treatment options include scraping off the opacity, dissolving it with sodium edetate, or using an excimer laser.

Vortex keratopathy

  • Vortex keratopathy, also known as corneal verticillata.
  • It is a distinctive pattern of corneal epithelial deposits that appear as whorl-like (vortex) lines swirling outward toward the periphery of the cornea.
  • Etiology:
    • Drugs: Chloroquine, Amiodarone (dose related), Tamoxifen, Indomethacin, Netarsudil.
    • Fabry disease

Salzmann nodular degeneration

  • A degenerative condition of the cornea.
  • Bluish-white, avascular nodules.
  • Located in the superficial stroma and Bowman’s membrane.
  • Typically occurs in individuals with a history of previous corneal disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about corneal degeneration is incorrect?

choices.text: Salzmann nodular degeneration affects the superficial stroma and Bowman’s membrane.
Vortex keratopathy is generally asymptomatic and associated with indomethacin intake.
Lipid keratopathy involves both intracellular and extracellular fat deposits.
Vortex keratopathy remains permanent even after discontinuing the offending medication.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vortex keratopathy remains permanent even after discontinuing the offending medication.

 

Explanation:

  • The condition of vortex keratopathy is reversible upon stopping the offending medication.

 

CORNEAL DEGENERATION

IMAGE

Vortex Keratopathy / Cornea verticillata

  • Whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium.
  • Causes: Long-term use of medications like amiodarone, chloroquine, phenothiazines, netrasudil and indomethacin, or associated with Fabry disease. (Option B ruled out)
  • Symptoms: Generally asymptomatic and harmless; can cause glare and surface discomfort.
  • Reversibility: The condition is reversible upon stopping the offending medication. (Option D)
  • Treatment: Surface discomfort may be managed with topical lubricants.

Lipid Keratopathy

  • Whitish or yellowish deposits in the cornea, composed mainly of cholesterol and fatty acids.
  • Primary Lipid Keratopathy: Rare, serum lipid levels are normal.
  • Secondary Lipid Keratopathy: Occurs in vascularized corneas due to diseases like corneal infections, interstitial keratitis, ocular trauma, glaucoma, or chronic iridocyclitis.
  • Fat Deposits: Initially intracellular but may become extracellular with necrosis of stromal cells. (Option C ruled out)

Salzmann nodular degeneration

  • A degenerative condition of the cornea.
  • Bluish-white, avascular nodules.
  • Located in the superficial stroma and Bowman’s membrane. (Option A ruled out)
  • Typically occurs in individuals with a history of previous corneal disease.
  • Tends to be slowly progressive.
  • May be treated with lamellar keratoplasty.

Correct answer: A) Nebular corneal opacity

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows a faint opacity covering the central cornea which suggests a Nebular opacity.
  • Although faint, a nebular opacity can severely impact vision, particularly if it covers the pupillary area.
  • The irregular refraction caused by the nebula distorts the image more than a denser opacity like leucoma, leading to greater visual discomfort and blurring.

Macular corneal opacity (Option B):

  • This semi-dense opacity affects the cornea less than a nebula regarding irregular refraction, but it still causes significant visual impairment.

 

Leucomatous corneal opacity (Option C):

  • While this dense white opacity blocks light more completely, it causes less irregular refraction than a nebula.
  • If it doesn't cover the entire pupillary area, it may not affect vision as much as a nebula.

 

Adherent leucoma (Option D):

  • This is a dense opacity associated with iris incarceration and is typically more significant in light blockage, but its effect on vision varies depending on the extent of iris involvement.

 

Management of corneal opacity:

  • Optical Iridectomy: This procedure can be used for central macular or leucomatous opacities when vision improves with pupil dilation.
  • Phototherapeutic Keratectomy (PTK): PTK uses an excimer laser, and is effective for treating superficial corneal opacities, such as nebulae.
  • Keratoplasty
  • Cosmetic-Coloured Contact Lenses: These lenses offer a cosmetic solution for unsightly scars in the eyes without visual potential.
  • Corneal Tattooing: It is mainly reserved for firm scars in eyes with no useful vision.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a history of gradual vision loss. O/E, multiple milky, granular deposits are seen in the anterior corneal stroma, with clear cornea between the deposits. Which type of stromal corneal dystrophy is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Granular Corneal Dystrophy, Type 1 (GCD1)

 

Explanation:

  • Multiple milky, granular deposits in the anterior corneal stroma, with a clear cornea between the deposits, indicate Granular corneal dystrophy Type 1.

 

Stromal Dystrophies

TGFB1 Corneal Dystrophies

These dystrophies are associated with mutations in the TGFB1 gene

Lattice Corneal Dystrophy (LCD)

 

(Option B ruled out)


 

Marked by amyloid deposits that form a lattice-like pattern within the corneal stroma. There are two subtypes:

  • LCD1: Typically presents in early childhood with lattice lines that spare the peripheral cornea, leading to recurrent erosions and visual impairment.
  • LCD2 (Gelsolin Type): Appears later in life and begins with lattice lines in the peripheral cornea, gradually affecting the centre.

 

Granular Corneal Dystrophy (GCD)

 

(Option A)


 

It is characterized by the deposition of hyaline material within the corneal stroma, with the following subtypes:

  • GCD1 (Classic): Presents in childhood with milky, granular deposits in the anterior stroma.
  • GCD2 (Granular-Lattice): Features both granular and lattice-like deposits, usually appearing in the first decade of life.

 

Other Stromal Dystrophies

Macular Corneal Dystrophy (MCD)

 

(Option C ruled out)

Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, this dystrophy is characterized by diffuse stromal haze and macular-shaped opacities, often causing significant visual impairment in childhood or early adulthood.

Schnyder Corneal Dystrophy (SCD)

 

(Option D ruled out)

An autosomal dominant condition marked by the deposition of cholesterol crystals in the corneal stroma, leading to ring-shaped opacities and progressive vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with the development of a "beaten-metal" appearance on the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy (FECD)

 

Explanation:

  • Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy is strongly associated with the "beaten-metal" appearance on Descemet's membrane.
  • It is a common type of endothelial dystrophy, particularly affecting older adults.

Posterior Polymorphous Corneal Dystrophy (PPCD) (Option A):

  • PPCD is a corneal dystrophy that often presents with unique lesions on the endothelium, such as nodules, vesicles, or band-like patterns that resemble railroad tracks.

 

Congenital Hereditary Endothelial Dystrophy (CHED) (Option B):

  • CHED is a genetic disorder where the endothelium is abnormal from birth or early childhood with diffuse corneal clouding, thickening, and decreased vision.

 

Keratoconus (Option C):

  • Keratoconus is a condition where the cornea progressively thins and bulges into a cone-like shape, causing irregular astigmatism and vision distortion.
  • It does not involve Descemet's membrane or produce the "beaten-metal" appearance.

Correct Answer: C) A-3, B-2, C-1

 

Explanation:

 

Fluorescein sodium

  • Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea.
  • Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast.
  • Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm), therefore staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used.

Rose bengal

  • Rose bengal is a derivative of fluorescein and is used to detect ocular surface damage.
  • It was initially theorized that rose bengal stains dead and devitalized tissue, but it is now thought to stain any part of the ocular surface which is not protected by an overlying tear film, specifically in areas lacking membrane-associated mucins.

Lissamine green

 

  • has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands.
  • The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions.
  • Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color.
  • As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a non-healing corneal ulcer in his right eye, despite two weeks of appropriate antibiotic therapy. The ulcer shows signs of impending perforation with severe thinning of the cornea. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increase the frequency of antibiotic eye drops.
Apply a pressure bandage and recommend strict bed rest.
Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue.
Start topical steroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Perform mechanical debridement and apply tissue adhesive glue

 

Explanation:

  • Mechanical debridement is necessary to remove necrotic material and promote healing in a non-healing ulcer.
  • Tissue adhesive glue is indicated to prevent perforation, especially when the perforation is less than 2mm.


 

Management of Non-Healing Ulcers

Management of Impending Perforation
  • Identify and Remove Causes: Local factors (e.g., ↑ IOP, foreign bodies, dacryocystitis) and systemic factors (e.g., diabetes, malnutrition) causing non-healing.
  • Mechanical Debridement: Scrape the ulcer floor to remove necrotic material under local anaesthesia to promote healing.
  • Cauterization: Using pure carbolic acid or 10-20% trichloroacetic acid in non-responding cases.
  • Bandage Soft Contact Lens: To aid healing by protecting the corneal surface.
  • Peritomy: Sever perilimbal conjunctival vessels to reduce excessive vascularization hindering healing.
  • Avoid Strain: Avoid sneezing, coughing, and straining, and maintain strict bed rest.
  • Pressure Bandage: To provide external support to the cornea.
  • Lower Intraocular Pressure: Use acetazolamide, mannitol, oral glycerol, timolol eye drops, and paracentesis if needed.
  • Tissue Adhesive Glue: Apply cyanoacrylate glue to prevent perforation, if perforation <2mm.
  • Bandage Soft Contact Lens: Used to support and protect the cornea.
  • Conjunctival Flap: Cover the cornea partially or completely with a conjunctival flap for additional support.
  • Amniotic Membrane Transplantation
  • Penetrating Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Perform a tectonic graft if suitable and available to prevent perforation or repair a perforated cornea if perforation >2-4mm.

 

Increasing the frequency of antibiotic eye drops (Option A) alone may not be sufficient in a case of impending perforation.

 

Applying a pressure bandage and bed rest (Option B) helps, but alone it is not sufficient without addressing the structural integrity of the cornea.

 

Topical steroids (Option D) are contraindicated as they can worsen the infection.

questions.text: Which layer of the cornea is primarily responsible for maintaining its transparency by regulating fluid content?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Endothelium

 

Explanation:

  • The innermost layer of the cornea is the endothelium which consists of a single layer of hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

 

Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

(Option C ruled out)
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane

(Option D ruled out)
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma

(Option A ruled out)
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)
  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

(Option B)
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: What is the primary metabolism of cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aerobic

 

Explanation:

  • The primary metabolism of the cornea is aerobic, where oxygen is used to generate energy, mainly through oxidative phosphorylation.
  • This is possible due to the oxygen supply from the tear film and the atmosphere, despite the cornea’s lack of blood vessels.
  • While the cornea does have some anaerobic metabolic processes, its primary metabolism is aerobic.
  • Activation of anaerobic glycolysis leads to lactic acid formation, resulting in metabolic acidosis causing inhibition of sodium- potassium pump, in turn leading to corneal edema. (Option A)
  • The primary metabolism of the lens is anaerobic, as it lacks blood vessels, and it relies on anaerobic glycolysis to generate ATP.
  • While both anaerobic and aerobic pathways are involved in corneal metabolism, aerobic metabolism is dominant. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not responsible for maintaining corneal transparency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corneal Nerve Supply

 

Explanation:

  • Corneal Nerve Supply is not directly involved in maintaining transparency.
  • It provides sensation to the cornea but does not influence the clarity of the corneal tissue.

Factors Responsible for Corneal Transparency:

  1. Anatomical Factors:
    • Corneal Epithelium and Tear Film: Ensures a uniform refractive index. (Option A ruled out)
    • Arrangement of Corneal Lamellae: Lattice structure (Maurice's theory) and specific refractive index variations (Goldmann and Benedek theory).
    • Avascularity: Absence of blood vessels in the cornea. (Option B ruled out)
  2. Physiological Factors:
    • Barrier Function: Limiting layers (epithelium and endothelium) maintain relative dehydration.
    • Endothelial Pumps: Control fluid transport through Naᐩ/Kᐩ-ATPase, bicarbonate-dependent ATPase, and Naᐩ/Hᐩ pumps, crucial for maintaining corneal dehydration. (Option D ruled out)
    • Evaporation: From the corneal surface.
    • Normal Intraocular Pressure (IOP): Helps maintain corneal shape.
    • Swelling Pressure (SP): Counteracts the imbibition effect of IOP.
    • Corneal Crystals/Proteins: Water-soluble proteins in keratocytes (e.g., transketolase, aldehyde dehydrogenase class 1A) contribute to transparency at the cellular level.

questions.text:
Match the following corneal assessment techniques with their correct descriptions:


	
		
			
			1) Keratometry
			
			
			a) Measures both anterior and posterior corneal surfaces.
			
		
		
			
			2) Placido's Disc
			
			
			b) Assesses the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface.
			
		
		
			
			3) Corneal Topography
			
			
			c) Evaluate the anterior curvature of the cornea and generate colour-coded maps.
			
		
		
			
			4) Corneal Tomography (Pentacam)
			
			
			d) Measures the curvature of the central cornea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Instrument

Image

Keratometry:

  • An objective method for measuring the curvature of the central cornea to estimate corneal astigmatism.
  • Principle of Keratometer: Measures corneal curvature by analyzing the size of the image formed by the anterior corneal surface, utilizing visible doubling.
  • Normal Keratometric Values:
    • Average: 45 D
    • Keratoconus >45 D
  • Types of Keratometers:
    • Javal-Schiotz Model
    • Bausch & Lomb Model
 

Auto refractive Keratometer

Keratoscopy or placido's disc:

  • A disc with alternating black and white circles.
  • Assesses the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface.
  • Normal Observation: Uniform, sharp image of circles on the cornea.
  • Irregularities on cornea: Distort the circles

Corneal topography:

  • Evaluates the anterior curvature of the cornea.
  • Generates colour-coded maps of the corneal surface's shape, curvature, and elevation.
  • Diagnoses conditions like keratoconus.
  • Assists in planning refractive surgeries.
  • Does not provide information about the posterior corneal surface.

Corneal tomography (Pentacam):

  • Measures both anterior and posterior corneal surfaces.
  • Provides a three-dimensional view of corneal structure.
  • Identifies subclinical keratoconus.
  • Assesses candidates for keratorefractive surgery.
  • Uses Scheimpflug imaging for high accuracy in corneal measurements.
  • Valuable for preoperative evaluations and monitoring disease progression.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Pachymetry measures corneal thickness and is used for diagnosing glaucoma
Specular Microscopy is used for photographing the corneal endothelium
Aesthesiometer measures corneal sensation and is used to assess neurotrophic keratitis
Aesthesiometer measures corneal sensation by evaluating the second cranial nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aesthesiometer measures corneal sensation by evaluating the second cranial nerve

 

Explanation:

  • Aesthesiometer (Esthesiometer) measures corneal sensation by evaluating the ophthalmic branch of the fifth cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve), not the second cranial nerve (optic nerve).
  • The fifth cranial nerve is responsible for sensory input from the cornea, which includes detecting tactile sensations.
  • The second cranial nerve (optic nerve) is primarily involved in vision, not sensation.

 

INSTRUMENT

IMAGE

Pachymetry

  • Measures corneal thickness.
  • Used for diagnosing and treating glaucoma. (Option A ruled out)
  • Assesses corneal thickness for refractive errors and LASIK surgery.
  • Evaluate corneal diseases such as corneal hydrops, keratoconus, and Fuchs’ dystrophy.
  • Monitors eye injuries.

Specular Microscopy:

  • Noninvasive technique for photographing and assessing the corneal endothelium. (Option B ruled out)
  • Evaluates preoperative endothelial health before high-risk surgeries.
  • Assesses the impact of lasers during refractive surgery.
  • Examines donor cornea before transplantation.
  • Pathologies Assessed Include Fuchs endothelial dystrophy, corneal dystrophies, posterior polymorphous dystrophy, congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy, uveitis, viral endothelitis, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy, ICE syndrome, trauma, pharmacological disruptions.
  

Esthesiometer (Aesthesiometer):

  • Measures corneal sensation (tactile sensation).
  • Evaluates the ophthalmic branch of the fifth cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve). (Option D ruled out)
  • Uses a cotton-tipped applicator for qualitative testing.
  • The handheld esthesiometer (Cochet-Bonnet) features a retractable nylon monofilament, adjustable up to 6 cm, with pressure increasing from 11 mm/gm to 200 mm/gm as the length decreases.
  • Diagnoses neurotrophic keratitis and assesses corneal health in long-term contact lens wearers. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 32 y/o contact lens wearer presents with a red, painful eye, blurred vision, and increased sensitivity to light. Examination reveals lid swelling, conjunctival chemosis, and a large corneal ulcer with greenish exudate, rapidly expanding with hypopyon. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including the irregular corneal ulcer with greenish exudate and hypopyon, along with a history of contact lens use, suggests a bacterial corneal ulcer.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is known for causing irregular corneal ulcers with greenish mucopurulent exudate, rapid progression, and hypopyon.
  • It is also common in contact lens-related infections.

Aetiology of Purulent Corneal Ulcer:

  • Corneal Epithelial Damage:
    • Due to Corneal abrasion, epithelial drying (xerosis, exposure keratitis), necrosis (keratomalacia), desquamation (bullous keratopathy), and trophic changes (neuroparalytic keratitis).
  • Pathogens Invading Intact Epithelium:
    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus aegyptius, Listeria species.
  • Sources of Infection:
    • Exogenous Sources: Conjunctival sac, lacrimal sac (dacryocystitis), infected foreign bodies, vegetative material, waterborne or airborne infections.
  • Common Bacteria Associated with Corneal Ulceration:
    • General: Staphylococci, Pseudomonas, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Enterobacteriaceae, Neisseria.
    • In Contact Lens Wearers: Pseudomonas is the most common cause. (Option C). Acanthamoeba is another differential in contact lens misuse.
  • All causative organisms:
    • Gram-positive Cocci: Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae.
    • Gram-negative Cocci: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Neisseria meningitidis.
    • Gram-positive Bacilli: Corynebacterium diphtheriae, C. xerosis, Bacillus cereus, Propionibacterium acne, Listeria, Clostridium.
    • Gram-negative Bacilli: Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, Proteus, E. coli, Serratia), Moraxella lacunata, Haemophilus influenzae.
    • Gram-positive Filamentous Bacteria: Actinomyces, Nocardia.
    • Mycobacteria: Non-tuberculous mycobacteria, M. tuberculosis.

 

Clinical Features of Bacterial Corneal Ulcers:

Symptoms:

  • Pain and foreign body sensation.
  • Watery eye (reflex hyper lacrimation).
  • Photophobia (light intolerance).
  • Blurred vision.
  • Redness of the eye.

Signs:

  • Lid swelling.
  • Blepharospasm (lid twitching).
  • Conjunctival chemosis and hyperemia.
  • Corneal ulcer characteristics:
    • Early stage: Epithelial defect with greyish-white infiltrate.
    • Established: Yellowish-white ulcer, swollen margins, necrotic floor, stromal oedema.
  • Specific bacterial features:
    • Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae: Oval, yellowish-white ulcer surrounded by clear cornea. (Options A & B ruled out)
    • Pseudomonas species: Irregular ulcer with greenish exudate, rapid spread, often with hypopyon. (Option C)
    • Enterobacteriaceae: Shallow ulcer with greyish-white suppuration, ring-shaped infiltrate. (Option D ruled out)
  • The anterior chamber may contain pus (hypopyon).
  • Muddy iris colour.
  • Small pupil due to iritis.
  • Possible raised intraocular pressure (inflammatory glaucoma).

questions.text: A 60 y/o woman presents with a painful red eye, photophobia, and a history of chronic use of corticosteroid eye drops. Examination reveals a corneal ulcer with necrosis extending deep into the corneal stroma, approaching Descemet's membrane. Which type of bacterial keratitis is this patient most at risk for?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Perforating Ulcer

 

Explanation:

  • Chronic use of corticosteroid eye drops can lead to thinning and weakening of the corneal tissue, making it more susceptible to deep infections.
  • When a corneal ulcer extends deep into the stroma, nearing Descemet's membrane, there is a high risk of perforation.
  • A perforating ulcer is a severe form of bacterial keratitis where the ulceration penetrates deeply, potentially leading to full-thickness corneal perforation.
  • The description of the ulcer penetrating deeply into the corneal stroma, approaching Descemet's membrane, suggests a Perforating Ulcer.

 

Types of Bacterial Keratitis

 

Localized Ulcer

Perforating Ulcer

Adherent Leucoma

Sloughing Ulcer
  • Begins with infiltration of inflammatory cells.
  • Leads to necrosis and sloughing of corneal tissue.
  • Healing occurs with epithelialization and scarring.
  • Deep penetration of ulcer reaching Descemet's membrane.
  • Risk of perforation with any strain, leading to intraocular complications.
  • Small perforations opposite the iris may heal rapidly, forming an adherent leucoma
  • Occurs when a small perforation is plugged by the iris.
  • Results in scar formation with permanent opacity.
  • Rapidly spreads across the cornea due to virulent organisms or weak immunity.
  • This leads to complete corneal destruction, iris prolapse, and formation of an anterior staphyloma with a pseudocornea.

Investigations for Bacterial Keratitis

  • Corneal Scraping: Obtained from ulcer edges and base after local anaesthesia and using a Kimura spatula.
  • Culture Media: Blood, chocolate, and thioglycollate broth for bacteria; non-nutrient agar for Acanthamoeba.
  • Staining: Gram and Giemsa stains to identify pathogens and analyze cell morphology.

Localized Ulcer (Option A): This term is too general and does not reflect the severe, deep nature of the ulcer described, which extends near Descemet's membrane, indicating a high risk of progression beyond just being "localized."

Adherent Leucoma (Option C): An adherent leucoma is a sequela or complication after a corneal perforation has occurred and healed with iris incarceration, not the type of bacterial keratitis the patient is currently at risk for.

Sloughing Ulcer (Option D): While necrosis is present and sloughing might occur, the most immediate and critical risk associated with an ulcer extending deep into the stroma and approaching Descemet's membrane is full-thickness penetration, not merely the shedding of necrotic tissue.

questions.text:
Clinical question:
Which of the following statements about the treatment of bacterial keratitis is incorrect?

choices.text: Cycloplegics like atropine can be used to reduce ciliary spasms and pain.
Ciprofloxacin (750mg twice daily) is given when the sclera gets involved.
Topical steroids should be started immediately to reduce inflammation.
Duo therapy with fortified cefazolin and tobramycin provides broad-spectrum coverage.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Topical steroids should be started immediately to reduce inflammation.

 

Explanation:

Topical steroids should not be used in bacterial keratitis as they can exacerbate the infection and delay healing.

Treatment of Bacterial Keratitis

  • Empirical Monotherapy:
    • A single fluoroquinolone (e.g., ofloxacin) is recommended but not standard practice due to high resistance rates in some regions.
    • Perforation is more likely in ulcers treated with ofloxacin.
  • Duo Therapy (Option D ruled out):
    • Use a combination of fortified cefazoline 5% and fortified tobramycin 1.3% to cover both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.
  • Ointments:
    • Ocular ointments can be beneficial at bedtime for milder cases and may serve as useful adjunctive therapy.
  • Cycloplegics (Option A ruled out):
    • Administer 1% atropine eye drops to reduce ciliary spasm pain, prevent posterior synechiae, increase blood supply, and decrease exudation.
    • 2% homatropine is an alternative.
  • Vitamin Supplements:
    • Vitamins A, B-complex, and C are recommended to promote early healing of the corneal ulcer.
  • Scleral involvement: (Option B ruled out):
    • In Scleral or systemic involvement cases, systemic antibiotics like oral ciprofloxacin (750 mg twice daily) or a combination of cephalosporin and aminoglycoside may be necessary.
  • Avoid Sponge/Pad and steroids.
    • Avoid using an eye sponge or pad to prevent infection from worsening by trapping bacteria.
    • Steroids should be avoided as they may exacerbate the infection and delay the healing process.

questions.text: What is the average thickness of the central cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 0.5 to 0.6 mm

 

Explanation:

  • 0.5 to 0.6 mm is the correct average thickness of the cornea at its central region, where it is thinnest.

 

CORNEA

Diameter

11-11.7 mm

Refractive Index

1.376

Refractive Power

45 Dioptre

Radius of curvature

Anterior - 7.8mm (Option D ruled out)

Posterior - 6.5mm

Thickness at the centre

0.5-0.6 mm (Option C)

Thickness at the periphery

1-1.2 mm (Option A ruled out)

 

0.8 to 0.9 mm (Option B): This thickness is greater than the actual average central thickness, suggesting a thicker cornea.

questions.text: A 60 y/o man from a tropical region presents with a painful, red eye and a corneal ulcer following recent exposure to decaying vegetable matter. Which is the most common fungal infection affecting the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Explanation:

  • Aspergillus fumigatus is a common causative organism of keratomycosis in tropical and subtropical regions and is often associated with exposure to decaying organic matter.

Keratomycosis Etiology Summary

  • Most Common Causative Organisms:
    • Aspergillus fumigatus: Most common in India and tropical regions.
    • Fusarium (Option B ruled out): Common in warm climates like Brazil.
    • Candida albicans (Option A ruled out): More frequent in temperate climates.
  • Mode of Infection:
    • Injury with Vegetative Material: Typically occurs after trauma with objects like thorns, wooden sticks, crop leaves, or decaying vegetable matter.
    • Common in Field Workers: Especially during harvesting season in rural and tropical areas.
    • Immunocompromised Individuals: Higher risk for developing fungal keratitis.
  • Special Considerations:
    • Candida albicans: Leading cause of endogenous endophthalmitis.
    • Mucormycosis (Option C ruled out) & Invasive Aspergillosis: Considered as the cause of orbital cellulitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 45 y/o man from a tropical region presents with a painful red eye, significant watering, and sensitivity to light after working in a garden with decaying plant material. The patient is diagnosed with keratomycosis. Which of the following is not an examination finding in keratomycosis?

choices.text: Feathery extensions at the margins of the corneal ulcer

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Extensive corneal vascularization

Explanation:

Extensive corneal vascularization is not seen in keratomycosis (fungal keratitis). In fact, corneal neovascularization is typically absent, especially in the acute stages. 

The following options are typical examination findings in keratomycosis:

Keratomycosis (Fungal Keratitis):

Aspect

Description

Clinical Features

• Pain and foreign body sensation

• Watering of the eye

• Photophobia

• Blurred vision

• Redness

Typical Examination Findings

• Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, with elevated rolled-out margins

• Pigmented Ulcer: Seen with dematiaceous fungi

• Feathery Extensions: Branching extensions into surrounding stroma (Option A)

• Sterile Immune Ring: Immune complex deposition (Option C)

• Satellite Lesions: Small lesions near main ulcer

• Hypopyon: Large, often non-sterile

• Endothelial Plaque: Dense accumulation of fibrin and leukocytes beneath lesion (Option D)

• Corneal Vascularization: Absent, especially in early disease (Option B is not seen)

Complications

• Rare corneal perforation

• Potential progression to endophthalmitis

Key Investigations

• Corneal Scraping: For smears and culture

• KOH Mount: Septate hyphae (Aspergillus, Fusarium) or yeast-like cells (Candida)

• Gram & Giemsa Stains: Inflammatory cells and fungal elements

• Culture: Sabouraud dextrose agar

• PCR: For early pathogen detection

• Confocal Microscopy: In vivo fungal visualization

• Anterior Chamber Paracentesis / Biopsy: If needed for deeper infection

Feathery extensions at the margins of the corneal ulcer (Option A): These are characteristic finger-like projections at the ulcer margins caused by filamentous fungi.

Sterile immune ring (Option C):  Also known as Wessely ring, formed at the interface of fungal antigens and host antibodies.

Endothelial plaque (Option D):  Dense, whitish deposits of fibrin and leukocytes under the stromal lesion.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with redness, pain, and decreased vision in his right eye. He reports a history of trauma to the eye with a plant material three days ago. O/E, there is a corneal ulcer with feathery edges and satellite lesions. Hypopyon is also noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical Natamycin

 

Explanation:

  • The history of trauma with plant material, along with the presence of a corneal ulcer with feathery edges and satellite lesions, is highly suggestive of fungal keratitis.
  • Natamycin is the first-line treatment for fungal keratitis, especially caused by filamentous fungi like Fusarium and Aspergillus.
  • It is effective in treating the type of fungal infection that is suggested by the clinical presentation in this patient.

 

Treatment of Keratomycosis (Fungal Corneal Ulcer):

Primary Treatment: Antifungal Medications:

  • Topical Antifungal Agents:
    • Natamycin
    • Voriconazole
    • Amphotericin B (effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium)
    • Nystatin (effective against Candida)
  • Oral Antifungal Agents (for severe ulcers with specific features):
    • Ketoconazole
    • Voriconazole
    • Indications for Oral Therapy:
      • Hypopyon
      • Perforation
      • Suspicion of endophthalmitis

Surgical Management (if unresponsive to medical therapy):

  • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
  • Cauterization Options:
    • Pure carbolic acid (100%)
    • Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%)
    • Povidone-iodine 5%
  • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

Management of Suspected Endophthalmitis:

  • Ultrasound: To check for exudates in the vitreous
  • Vitreous Tap & intravitreal injections of antibiotics and antifungals (amphotericin B) if confirmed
  • Surgical Options (if medical therapy fails):
    • Corneal graft
    • Conjunctival flap

Topical Moxifloxacin (Option A):

  • Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic effective against bacterial infections, not fungal infections.
  • Given the history of trauma with plant material and the appearance of a corneal ulcer with feathery edges and satellite lesions, the most likely diagnosis is fungal keratitis.
  • Therefore, moxifloxacin would not be appropriate.

Oral Acyclovir (Option C):

  • Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used primarily for herpes simplex virus infections.
  • It would not be effective for a fungal corneal ulcer, making it an inappropriate choice in this scenario.

Intravitreal Amphotericin B (Option D):

  • Intravitreal Amphotericin B is used in cases of fungal endophthalmitis, not as an initial treatment for keratitis.
  • Although hypopyon suggests severe infection, the primary treatment should still be topical antifungal agents unless there is confirmed or high suspicion of endophthalmitis requiring intravitreal therapy.

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient presents with eye redness, excessive tearing, and sensitivity to light. O/E, you observe dendritic ulcers and decreased corneal sensation. Based on these findings, which is the most likely etiological agent responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)

 

Explanations:

  • HSV keratitis is characterized by dendritic ulcers on the cornea, which are branching, tree-like lesions.
  • HSV also commonly causes decreased corneal sensation.

 

Examination Findings in Viral Keratitis:

Signs:

  • Swollen Epithelial Cells: Early signs presenting as swollen, opaque cells in a coarse punctate or stellate pattern.
  • Dendritic Ulcer: Characteristic linear, branching ulcer with terminal bulbs; stains with fluorescein.
  • Geographic Ulcer: Enlarged amoeboid-shaped ulcer, often due to inappropriate steroid use.

 

  • Rose Bengal Staining: Stains virus-laden cells at the ulcer edges, aiding in differentiation from other conditions.
  • Reduced Corneal Sensation: Result of corneal nerve damage.
  • Subepithelial Haze: Mild haziness was observed in the subepithelial layer.
  • Anterior Chamber Activity: Mild inflammatory reaction in the anterior chamber.
  • Elevated IOP: Increased intraocular pressure, requiring monitoring.
  • Persistent Punctate Erosions (PEE): Residual erosions and epithelial irregularities after healing, resolving spontaneously without indicating recurrence.

 

Specific Findings Based on Virus Type:

1) Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Keratitis:

  • Dendritic Ulcers: Branching, tree-like ulcers.
  • Geographic Ulcers: Larger, amoeboid-shaped ulcers.
  • Stromal Keratitis: Inflammation of the corneal stroma, leading to oedema, infiltrates, and scarring.
  • Disciform Keratitis: Central, disc-shaped inflammation in the stroma.

 

2) Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO): (Option B)

  • Vesicles and Scars: Painful rash and blisters following the involvement of ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Nummular Keratitis: Large, coin-shaped, subepithelial corneal infiltrates.

 

  • Scleritis: Inflammation of the sclera, causing pain and redness.
  • Iritis: Inflammation of the iris leading to pain, photophobia, and blurred vision.

3) Adenovirus (Option A):

  • Adenoviruses are known for causing epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) and may present with conjunctivitis and keratitis.
  • They are less likely to cause dendritic ulcers, which are specific to HSV.

4) Chlamydia trachomatis (Option D):

  • Chlamydia typically causes trachoma or inclusion conjunctivitis, which may involve conjunctival scarring and corneal pannus, but not dendritic ulcers.

questions.text: A 35 y/o patient presents with pain, redness, photophobia, and decreased vision in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals a dendritic ulcer on the cornea. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Topical acyclovir and cycloplegics

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with pain, redness, photophobia, and decreased vision in the right eye, along with a dendritic ulcer on the cornea.
  • This clinical picture is classic for Herpes Simplex Keratitis (HSK), an infection of the cornea caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

Treatment:

  • Topical Acyclovir: This antiviral medication is the first-line treatment for HSV keratitis. It directly targets the herpes simplex virus, reducing viral replication and promoting healing of the corneal ulcer.
  • Cycloplegics: These medications help to relieve pain caused by ciliary muscle spasms and prevent the formation of synechiae (adhesions) in the iris.


 

Treatment of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Keratitis:

 

Topical Therapy:

  • Antivirals:
    • Common Agents:
      • Aciclovir 3% ointment: 5 times daily.
      • Ganciclovir 0.15% gel: 5 times daily.
      • Trifluridine: Up to 9 times daily.
    • Older Agents: Idoxuridine and vidarabine (less common due to lower efficacy/higher toxicity).
  • Other Topical Medications:
    • Antibiotics: Prevent secondary bacterial infections, especially with epithelial defects.
    • Cycloplegics: (e.g., Homatropine 1%) Relieve pain and photophobia by paralyzing ciliary muscles and dilating the pupil.
    • Steroids:
      • Epithelial Keratitis: Contraindicated due to the risk of worsening infection and corneal perforation.
      • Stromal Keratitis: Used cautiously with antivirals to control inflammation and reduce scarring.

Oral Therapy:

  • Antivirals:
    • Indications: immunocompromised patients, children, severe ocular surface disease, intolerance/resistance to topical treatment.
    • Prophylaxis: L
      • ow-dose oral acyclovir (400 mg twice daily) reduces recurrence.
      • Alternatives include valaciclovir (500 mg once daily) and famciclovir.
  • Steroids: Generally avoided but may be used with caution in severe stromal inflammation as an adjunct to topical therapy.

Surgical Management:

  • Debridement: Removal of infected epithelial cells, helpful in resistant epithelial keratitis.
  • Keratoplasty:
    • Indication: Severe corneal scarring after at least a year of infection-free status.
    • Risk of Recurrence:
      • HSV keratitis may recur post-keratoplasty. Eyes with extensive corneal vascularization are at higher risk of graft rejection and recurrence.
      • Prophylactic oral acyclovir is recommended.

Topical steroids and antibiotics (Option A):

  • Topical steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of active epithelial HSV keratitis, as they can suppress the immune response and worsen the viral infection, potentially leading to complications like corneal perforation.
  • Antibiotics are not needed unless there is a secondary bacterial infection, which is not indicated here.

Oral acyclovir and lubricants (Option B):

  • While oral acyclovir is used in more severe or recurrent cases of HSV keratitis, topical acyclovir is preferred as the initial treatment.
  • Lubricants can be supportive but are not the primary treatment.

Oral steroids and topical antibiotics (Option D):

  • Oral steroids are contraindicated in HSV keratitis, similar to topical steroids, as they can exacerbate the infection.
  • Topical antibiotics are unnecessary unless there's evidence of bacterial superinfection.

questions.text: A 50 y/o male presents with decreased vision, redness, and a dull sensation in his R/E. He has a history of trigeminal neuralgia for which he underwent a Gasserian ganglion block. O/E, there is decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neurotrophic Keratopathy

 

Explanation:

  • Neurotrophic keratopathy is characterized by decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation due to trigeminal nerve damage or dysfunction.
  • The patient’s history of Gasserian ganglion block, a procedure known to impair the trigeminal nerve, strongly supports this diagnosis.

Causes of Decreased Corneal Sensation:

  1. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Infections (Option B):
    • HSV keratitis typically presents with dendritic ulcers on the cornea and is associated with pain, photophobia, and possibly vesicular skin lesions.
    • However, the history of a Gasserian ganglion block and the description of decreased corneal sensation point more toward neurotrophic keratopathy.
  2. Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus:
    • Caused by varicella zoster virus.
    • Leads to decreased corneal sensation.
    • Ocular complications include:
      • Punctate epithelial keratitis.
      • Nummular keratitis.
      • Stromal keratitis.
      • Iridocyclitis.
      • Scleritis.
  3. Keratomalacia (Option A)
    • Result of vitamin A deficiency.
    • The cornea becomes dull and insensitive.
    • Signs include haziness and yellow infiltrates (not seen in this patient)
    • Can progress to corneal necrosis.
  4. Neurotrophic Keratopathy (Option C):
    • Caused by trigeminal nerve paralysis.
    • Decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation.
    • May follow procedures like Gasserian ganglion removal or blockage, often used in treating trigeminal neuralgia.
  5. Neuroparalytic Keratopathy (Option D):
    • This condition occurs due to facial nerve paralysis, leading to lagophthalmos (inability to close the eye) and subsequent corneal exposure.
    • The patient's history does not suggest facial nerve paralysis, making this less likely.

questions.text: A 65 y/o woman presents with a painful rash on her forehead and eyelid. She also reports blurred vision and photophobia. O/E, she has conjunctivitis, punctate epithelial keratitis, and iridocyclitis. Which of the following is a chronic ocular complication she is at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Corneal Scarring

 

Explanations:

  • This is a chronic complication that can develop after the acute phase of herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
  • It results from damage to the cornea due to keratitis and can lead to vision impairment.

Ocular Manifestations of Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO):

 

  • Hutchinson’s rule: The eye will be involved if the nose tip is involved. As it indicates nasociliary nerve involvement.
  • Vesicles are present on the nose. Whenever there is involvement of the nose and skin lesions, this is called the Htchinson’s sign.

 

Acute Ocular Manifestations:

  • Conjunctivitis: Redness and inflammation of the conjunctiva. (Option C ruled out)
  • Keratitis:
    • Punctate Epithelial Keratitis: Coarse and irregular lesions.
    • Nummular Keratitis: Larger, disc-shaped lesions.
    • Disciform keratitis.
  • Iridocyclitis: Inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, causing pain, photophobia, and blurred vision.
  • Keratouveitis and endothelitis: Leads to acute endothelial cell loss
  • Episcleritis and Scleritis: Inflammation of the episclera or sclera, resulting in pain and redness. (Option A ruled out)

Chronic Ocular Manifestations:

 

  • Post-herpetic neuralgia:
    • When pain persists despite the resolution of the eruptive phase.
    • In the long term, this leads to some anaesthesia in the affected skin, known as anaesthesia dolorosa.
  • Corneal lesions:
    • Neuroparalytic ulceration.
    • Neurotrophic Keratopathy
    • Corneal scarring
    • Exposure keratitis
    • Mucous plaque keratitis (Sudden development of elevated mucous plaque which stains on rose bengal)
  • Lid lesions: D/t scarring. Include ptosis, trichiasis & entropion.
  • Secondary Glaucoma: Increased intraocular pressure (IOP) leading to optic nerve damage and vision loss.

Recurrent Infections: Less common and usually milder than the initial episode.

 

Secondary Glaucoma (Option D):

  • While secondary glaucoma is a chronic complication of herpes zoster ophthalmicus, it is more related to increased intraocular pressure due to inflammation or damage.
  • Corneal scarring is a direct result of keratitis and is specifically related to the chronic effects on the cornea, making it a more direct chronic complication from the given options.
